titleStmt.title: Variants of ǧāʔ inflection: 3SG.M in PFV
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for ǧāʔ inflection: 3SG.M in PFV

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

item.label: ǧa - ža - ya - ga / ǧā etc

cit.quote: Very old speakers (70+) and some old speakers use ǧa or ža along with ʔəža.
Very old speakers (70+) and some old speakers use ǧa or ža along with ʔəža.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".
Belinkov (2019) recorded one older speaker who used ǧā without the inital a
preferred form for third person with vowel-inital suffixes
The third person is always a communis, thus, the originally female form jat can also be used here.
The third person is always a communis, thus, the originally female form jat can also be used here.
